data.text: Bicycle Touring in the Summer Heat: What Do You Do and How Do You Prepare?
I'm looking for some advice about cycling in the heat (30+ C) 1) How do you deal with it in the moment? (eg clothing, nutrition, mindset, breathing) 2) How do you prepare for it?

I have cycled in tropical countries many times over the years. Never really had an issue with the heat, even if I am from Denmark. I find that cycling gives you a breeze that makes you feel less hot. I much prefer to cycle in the heat than walking or standing still.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: I would agree with . Just need a water top up more often. I don't even like hot weather too much and was still fine.
data.author: Jon Belt

data.text: Perhaps, ride early in the day, Siesta in the middle, stay in the shade, then start later in the evening when it cools off?
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: 1. Sunscreen. Even when it doesn‚Äôt look like it‚Äôs needed. I mean, I don‚Äôt really do it, but I regret not doing it every time. 2. Cycle early in the morning and late in the afternoon/evening. Avoid 12-14. Stop for lunch, ice cream, soda, casual sex, whatever. Just don‚Äôt bike in the worst heat. 3. Sprinkling your clothes with water might be more cooling that taking them off. 4. Shorter distances. Slower pace. Whatever makes you more comfortable. 5. EDIT: i have heard that drinking hot drinks is actually better in hot weather (as they warm us up and the difference between our temperature and the outside isn‚Äôt that big like it would be if we drank cold drinks), and to be honest, I love hot tea on a hot day. Maybe it‚Äôs worth giving it a try!
data.author: Kay Anky JS

data.text: Start earlier, drink a lot of water, wear sunscreen, try to protect your skin as much as possible wearing a light long sleeve shirt, avoid biking in the hottest hours. We carried a cooler in the hottest days with some ice lol.
data.author: Malib√© Contreras

data.text: Have enough water (I drunk more than 5 litres a day). At least some of it enriched with minerals and vitamins (e.g. tabletes from Lidl or Walmart). Use light colored (white or silver) helmet and sun cream. And you would be fine.
data.author: Martin Mastalka

data.text: Cycled in India last month : I started really early stop between 11.00 and 15.00 Used long sleeves event if I completely sweaty Drink 8L of water per day ü•µ
data.author: Mattis Bl√ø

data.text: I did it last summer in Croatia with the heatwave. I have cycled 5.30/6.00 till 10.30/11.00, then again few hours in the early evening A few times I was trapped in the road at 12.00 with no shadows and that was not fun at all üòÅ. Water, water, water, long sleeves, a hat and some rehidromix :).
data.author: Petra Po

data.text: Fluid replacement is a huge deal-over and above just water. If your cycling tropical-then get lots of coconut water (usually avail at every street crossing/town), and fruit juices. Bananas are a great and simple source of potassium for those worked muscles. And salt! If you‚Äôre cramping at night-get a teaspoon of salt mixed with water (or whatever..) in you. Remarkable how quick the body responds to the stuff. Loose, white, cotton shirts, and wide brim hats.. Keep the sun off you as much as you can. I love the sun, but 10 hours cycling in it is murderous. Starting early in the day, and stopping on the early side for a 2 hour siesta was very helpful, though sometimes took the wind out of the sails- And sunscreen! Yeahhh. Lots of the gunk. Don‚Äôt worry what you look like.
data.author: Paul Agnew

data.text: I like that you use cotton shirts. I'm having trouble putting up with polyester on my skin, makes me agitated. Do you only use cotton for your tours?
data.author: Juliette Polg√°r

data.text: no, I‚Äôve got a couple light merino shirts that are quite nice/cooling to wear also. Just the cost factor on those beauties! Cotton long sleeves are so much cheaper and obtainable everywhere. I‚Äôve got a tight light poly sun shirt I‚Äôll wear for periods also. Keeps me cool, but not the best on the skin.
data.author: Paul Agnew

data.text: There is a point (roughly around zone 2) where the air cooling is more than any heat generated by exertion, so you tend to actually feel quite comfortable. There is a point where that simply isn't possible based on both humidity and heat, but for temperatures that low, it's fine. I tend to carry a good deal of water (2x40 oz hydroflasks) and stick to populated areas. If it's extreme heat I usually wake up really early (pre-dawn) and ride till mid-day then rest. As for preparation, you just gotta ride in the heat to get used to it.
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: Cover up. Lots of water
data.author: Wayne Macdougall

data.text: This Summer maybe 40 ¬∞C, lot of water, a day also 8 liters, rarely pee, almost only sweat. Cotton shorts and T-shirt. No training, my first time a month trip 1000km üòÉ. So do not be afraid üòâ
data.author: Johnnie Walker

data.text: Long loose sleeves. They will keep you cooler. Look for merino wool shirts.
data.author: Kevin Merrill

data.text: so you use merino wool in hot temperatures?? I was wondering about that because I can't stand all the polyester fabrics on my skin and cotton seems heavy and maybe not a good idea because it doesn't dry fast enough
data.author: Juliette Polg√°r

data.text: Vietnam, it was over 100f. A brimmed hat under your helmet also helps extremely well. I made this one, but they have commercially made ones that go over your helmet
data.author: Kevin Merrill

data.text: Thin Merino wool is amazing in any temperature. Most people think of wool as a big heavy thing to keep warm.. Wool is amazing when it gets wet it‚Äôs fibres seal to stop some wind chill and it just breathes.. Not the cheapest but I found some at a vintage clothes fair.
data.author: Steel Bikes

data.text: Hydrate before you start. And the one bottle per hour rule is inadequate above that temperature.
data.author: Tom Duffy

data.text: I‚Äôm currently on a bike trip through West Africa and have been in highs of 45C, my first time cycling in a hot place üò¨ Most important thing is starting as early as possible. I keep going until it‚Äôs unbearable, take a long break, and finish the ride when the sun is less strong. Getting 2/3 to 3/4 of the ride done in the morning is the sweet spot for me. Obviously drink as much water as you can, and cold sugary drinks are an amazing addition at the tale end of a ride.
data.author: Alexander DeVenne

data.text: 1)Drink more than you're ever thirsty for. I think scout's rule is that you're supposed to pee at least seven times a day during a day's exertion but you can't really overdrink while cycling in the heat. 2) wet your clothes as much and as often as possible in cold water 3) travel in the cool - early in the morning and evening if you can. That middle bit - chill out and relax in the shade somewhere, preferably submerged like a hippo with only ears showing 4)remember to replenish salt - you'll be sweating like a bastard and it makes the heat-hangover worse if you don't replace as you go 5) cover your head and shade your face at the very least. Headache and eye strain are hard to lose in the heat. Good luck!!
data.author: Shona MacArthur

data.text: Very good concrete tips!
data.author: Ding Gerrous

data.text: only because I did none of them the first few days üòÅ live and learn
data.author: Shona MacArthur

data.text: 'Live and learn, indeed.
data.author: Ding Gerrous

data.text: submerged like a hippo ü¶õ üòÇ
data.author: Anja Verschoor

data.text: Perfect Neck cooling towel...on Amazon. Around the neck and tuck it through that opening to hold in the wind. Mine is the 29 x 11 and holds 9 full ounces of water. The wind from riding makes the thing frigid.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: a modern take on the cowboy neck scarf. Even a simple cotton rag kept wet and wrapped round your neck works quite well. Also an old pro trick - cut off the foot section of some ladies tights. Stuff it with ice and tuck it under your shirt below the back of your neck.
data.author: Bob Stafford

data.text: Electrolytes. Fuel up before you go. Cover up so you don‚Äôt get burned. I don‚Äôt use sunscreen but cover up instead. Will actually cool you down a bit. 4 years ago we rode through the Mohave in May. It was over 100 by 9am and no services on long stretches. It was a mental challenge having to conserve water.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: In Georgia and South-Carolina the heat was making me sick. I had to get up at 6 o‚Äôclock in the morning and stop at 11am. In Australia it was 40‚Äô I cycled from tree to tree and finally gave up and turned around to wait at the campground for cooler weather. Just turn around if it‚Äôs too hot.
data.author: Sarah Delafortrie

data.text: tree to tree. I've done too. That's when you know it's hot.
data.author: Stuart Bible

data.text: Sun sleeves and leg sleeves protect from getting sunburn. Lots of water. A huge rimmed light hat to protect your face and neck from the sun. Take lots of short breaks. Make sure you pee every hour while cycling to prevent dehydration.
data.author: Javier Col√≥n

data.text: I just went through a 3 day heat wave in spain...it was intense. I couldn't carry enough water. I had to get off the road and recoup.
data.author: Leslie Carvery

data.text: Had mid-to-high 90s with 75% humidity in Missouri (pronounced "Misery" üòú). On the worst days, I would ride until early afternoon and break for a couple of hours to escape the peak heat, and get a couple more hours in before calling it a day. Other than that, hydration, hydration, hydration. I personally prefer using sun sleeves as opposed to sunscreen, and I also use DaBrim around my helmet, providing me a shade. I actually felt cooler when I was rolling then when stopped.
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: That blesses me to know that those days were some of your hottest (while we were both in MO) even though you had rides through the desert for all those miles. Helps my own thoughts as I head towards those same hot roads. It's kind of cold here in Tulsa today.
data.author: Scott Batch

data.text: there is an absolute difference between a humid-heat and a dry-heat ü§Ø
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: Consciously & actively prehydrate & pre-carb-up before each interval of 10-15 miles, so you are never behind the satiation curve. Like at least a pint of water before each interval, & an oat bar or 2. Always try to stop in the shade where any breeze can maximize the evaporative cooling of your sweat & splashed moisture. Cover a lot of skin so you're shaded & can always splash your clothes with water to increase the evaporation. Consciously & actively remember to breath thru your nose to minimize flushing moisture out your mouth.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: Its when you stop it really hits you! Floods of sweat and many concerned on lookers as your face goes even redder.
data.author: Dane Hardinge

data.text: Echoing the other comments. Start as early as possible, sunscreen but covering up is better (very loose, light cotton). When we've been in extreme heat (35c+) for extended periods we start and end the day with dioralyte (or similar, but if you can't get then sugar and salt in squash will work) the main thing is that you are peeing and it is straw coloured. Heatstroke is not nice, so best avoided, also you may get horrible muscle cramps.
data.author: Lynne Sixtyodd Roberts

data.text: I've been caught a couple of times with heat stroke. Blood in the urine and cramps were the first signs on both occasions for me. Easy fixed with more frequent water and magnesium / electrolyte type supplements, prehydrate, cover up, rest frequently. If all that still doesn't seem to work. Go nocturnal and sleep days and work nights.
data.author: Stuart Bible

data.text: Whatever who says don‚Äôt ride in very high dew (over 72)points which can be dangerous and fatal. Other than the obvious things like hydration and easier pace some people adapt to heat better than others and some never do.
data.author: Ali Albayrak

data.text: When I encounter that type of heat, I find some shade and rehydrate until the evening. You can ride but you have to add salt(s) to your fluids or take salt tablets. I had to do this at Ironman Florida.
data.author: Ed Gaviria

data.text: I live in vietnam. I ride that heat all the time. Strangely (or not so strangely) I've adopted the "cover everything" stance. I wear a full length riding jersey, cool max buff, and full or 3/4 length bib. I hydrate with salts and electolyte drinks frequently....i live for japanese B vitamin jelly packs. I ride early and get off the road by noon. If I am doing a longer distance, I try to break around 12 and resume around 2.
data.author: Kattina Rabdau

data.text: As above, drink water before you think you do, if you are in a group remind each other to drink, you will make bad decisions the more dehydrated you get. Suncream helps more than you think. If you get burnt you will still be cooking during the evening and will start off worse the next day and the day after each day making worse decisions. Wear a hat to keep the sun off the face. The hottest time of the day is late afternoon when the sun has had a chance to heat the ground up and you get heat from both the sun and the ground so be aware of that. One way I have found keeping water cool is to wrap a water bladder in one of those space/survival/emergancy/foil blankets one of those will keep your water cool for hours, and drinkable into the late afternoon.
data.author: Barry Warner

data.text: Take a water break when you get hot. If your body can't sweat you can die, drink water and Take salt tablets.
data.author: Clyde Slade

data.text: Electrolytes are really important
data.author: Scott Fowler

data.text: In that level of heat, I would stay out of the sun. Cycling at night can be a good option if you're in an area without nocturnal apex predators that might eat you.
data.author: Paul McMahon

data.text: Start early in the morning (3 am) ,have a rest and then cycle from 5pm.take some hydration water bags plus mineral supplement .avoid sugar and energy bars as it dehydrate you, I have done over a 1000 KM in the Sahara desert !!!
data.author: Robert Mrki

data.text: Under armour heat gear is a blessing. I have a long sleeve heat gear shirt that's compression fit and it's like wearing a fan or ac. Gets super sweaty? Take it off, wring it out and soak in a little water. In a half hour it will be dry and doing its thing again.
data.author: Lawrence Miller

data.text: Don't really change my clothes. Do wear thinner socks. Carry more water to actually pour over my head, which I do often and wet my half fingered gloves. Top up on supplements like calmag and stay hydrated
data.author: Annie Mtb North

data.text: Sleep during the day and ride all night
data.author: Pdl Breaking

data.text: Lots of water. Lots and lots of water. And listen to your body. if you need to sit in the shade for a bit, do so. Cycled through a heat wave last summer, but did most of my riding between 8 and 11am and 3 and 9pm. If possible, ride at night.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: In Badajoz, Spain, the average temperature in July and August is 42, 43 degrees, with peaks of up to 46. To travel like this you need a lot of water, even though in luggage and sunscreen factor 50. From 1 pm you look for a municipal swimming pool and rest in it until 7 pm more or less. That's what I do and it's okay it's worse the cold I think. A greeting
data.author: Federico De Tena Ruiz

data.text: Just cycle as long as you feel well. your body will tell you how much to rest and how much to drink. depending on the humidity, 30 degrees Celsius and More are manageable. all the best :)
data.author: Simon Sieder

data.text: Driking more fluid than you want to.
data.author: ‡∏Å‡∏§‡∏ï‡∏¢‡πå ‡∏ó‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏á

data.text: Keep the pace down. Thin white long sleeve shirts. Drink and Salts/Potassium.. A lot of people in hot countries have home made lemonade with salt in.
data.author: Steel Bikes

data.text: Acclimatise to the heat and humidity. Garmin even have a heat acclimatisation folder on the 1030 plus edge.
data.author: Marcus Richardson

data.text: Have some arm warmers that you soak in water every chance you get, they will act as coolers while the water evaporates.
data.author: Per Sjunnesson

data.text: Ride very early. Rest and holiday stuff from 10am until 3pm. Ride very late. That is in the ideal world and is the best way to do it. If it is 40+ you will be affected regardless of how much you drink. You get to a stage where your sweat output is on level to your drink input. You physically find it difficult to take in more liquid. Dont get to that stage as it can take days to recover.
data.author: Steve Lindley
